User Positioning

Introduction

The eye tracker has an optimal working distance between 50 and 60 cm. The API has 2 ways to let the users know where they must be located:

  • The distanceFactor variable in IrisbondAPI::DATA_CALLBACK
  • The positioning GUI in the API

Distance factor

The distance factor is a variable that provides information about the distance between the user and the eye tracker.

It can take values between -1 and 1, where 0 is the optimal distance. At this distance, the image quality is excellent and the eye detection is optimal.

When the user moves far from the eye tracker, the value will decrease to -1, which means the user is too far. When the user moves close to the eye tracker, the value will increase up to 1, which means the user is too close. It is recommended to position the user in such range that distanceFactor is between -0.5 and 0.5.

Any application that implements its own GUIs must get the distanceFactor variable (and others) from IrisbondAPI::DATA_CALLBACK.

Positioning GUI

An alternative and very simple way to position the user at the optimal distance is to show the API default positioning GUI.

2 functions are required for this task:

  • showPositioningWindow() will show the default positioning GUI
  • hidePositioningWindow() will close the default positioning GUI

In applications where style is a critical point, this GUI may be too simple or may have a different style from the other GUIs, and implementing an own GUI may be the best option. For simple applications or for a proof of concept, this default GUI can be enough.
